steps.title: Use a soft bristle brush to remove loose dirt and debris.
steps.content: Use a soft bristle brush to remove loose dirt and debris. Swipe the brush over the material gently in small, circular motions. A soft toothbrush can be used to get into harder to reach areas. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Buff out marks with an eraser.
steps.content: Buff out marks with an eraser. For scuff marks , an eraser can help to rub away the transferred color on the shiny leather. Gently rub the eraser against the scuff, clearing away any eraser shavings by using the bristle brush as you work. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Remove tough stains using rubbing alcohol or petroleum jelly.
steps.content: Remove tough stains using rubbing alcohol or petroleum jelly. Apply a small amount of the rubbing alcohol or petroleum jelly to a cotton swab or paper towel. Rub the mark using a little bit of force, being careful not to push too hard. After 15-20 seconds, wipe the area dry with a cloth. [3] X Research source If the stain is particularly stubborn, you might have to repeat this process a few times.

steps.title: Wipe the outside of the shoe using a damp cloth and mild soap.
steps.content: Wipe the outside of the shoe using a damp cloth and mild soap. Make sure the cloth is only damp by ringing it out. You should use 1 small drop of non-detergent liquid soap on the damp cloth. Wipe in small circular motions on all surfaces of the shoe that are patent leather. [4] X Research source While patent leather shoes are coated with a clear gloss, they aren’t actually waterproof. It’s best to use as little water as possible to clean and never wear them for long periods of time in wet conditions.

steps.title: Buff the shoes with a soft polishing cloth.
steps.content: Buff the shoes with a soft polishing cloth. Again, wipe in small circular motions to remove any excess water. To make sure that the shoes dry thoroughly after cleaning, set them out for at least 24 hours at room temperature. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Apply olive/mineral oil or petroleum jelly if your shoes are sticky.
steps.content: Apply olive/mineral oil or petroleum jelly if your shoes are sticky. Add a small amount of the oil or petroleum jelly to a cloth and wipe onto the leather in small, circular motions. Let it sit on the shoes for 20-40 minutes and then wipe clean with a dry cloth. [6] X Research source If the shoes are still sticky, allow them to sit overnight to see if the stickiness dries. If not, it may be the case that the glue on your shoes has degraded due to humidity and ruined the leather.

steps.title: Store patent leather items in a safe and dry location.
steps.content: Store patent leather items in a safe and dry location. After cleaning, make sure you’re keeping your shoes in a location that is safe for long-term storage. A good storage space is dry, room-temperature, and clean. [7] X Research source It’s a good idea to keep them stored with their shoe trees so that they retain their form. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Vacuum the entire surface area of the furniture piece.
steps.content: Vacuum the entire surface area of the furniture piece. [9] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 8 November 2020. Dirt and dust can collect in the nooks and crannies of sofas and their cushions. Use the brush extension of the vacuum to lift dirt and reach difficult areas. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Add a few drops of non-detergent liquid soap to distilled water.
steps.content: Add a few drops of non-detergent liquid soap to distilled water. [11] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 8 November 2020. This will make a cleaning solution that won’t damage the coated leather. It’s important to use a non-detergent soap so the coating on the furniture is not dulled by harmful chemicals. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Dampen a microfiber cloth in the cleaning solution.
steps.content: Dampen a microfiber cloth in the cleaning solution. Dip one small part of the cloth into the solution at first. Make sure the cloth is just damp, not saturated. You might need to ring it out a little bit before using it. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe an inconspicuous spot on the furniture with the solution.
steps.content: Wipe an inconspicuous spot on the furniture with the solution. Make sure it’s not an area that you can see normally on the piece of furniture. This will be your test spot to ensure that there’s no marking or staining from your cleaning solution. [14] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 8 November 2020. Wait for it to dry or gently wipe it dry after a few moments. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe the couch from top to bottom using your cleaning solution.
steps.content: Wipe the couch from top to bottom using your cleaning solution. If there’s no discoloration on the test patch, continue wiping the couch. [16] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 8 November 2020. Work from top to bottom, using large circular motions and re-moistening the cloth as needed. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe the couch with just distilled water.
steps.content: Wipe the couch with just distilled water. After applying the cleaning solution, go back over the couch with a cloth dipped in only water. Work from top to bottom again, using large circular motions. This will help remove any residue from the soap. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Dry your patent leather furniture piece.
steps.content: Dry your patent leather furniture piece. Use a soft, microfiber towel to dry the furniture. Your couch should never be soaking wet, as saturation will cause irreversible damage to the material. [19] X Research source Never use a hair dryer or fan to dry the leather. Although they might be quicker, they can cause dehydration of the leather. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Condition the leather to ensure it retains its softness.
steps.content: Condition the leather to ensure it retains its softness. To replace natural oils that leather loses when it is cleaned, apply a leather cream using a clean cloth. Let the cream dry completely and buff to shine if needed. [21] X Research source Avoid using DIY cleaning or conditioning solutions that include vinegar, as it can strip the glossy coating from the patent leather.

steps.title: Use a small amount of petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol for tough stains.
steps.content: Use a small amount of petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol for tough stains. Apply the petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol to a cotton swab or paper towel and gently it rub into the stained area. Wipe the area dry after 15-20 seconds, and reapply if necessary until the stain disappears. After the stain is gone, wipe down the area with a damp cloth and dry it completely.

steps.title: Buff out large scuff marks with an eraser.
steps.content: Buff out large scuff marks with an eraser. For large marks, an eraser can provide friction to remove the transferred color from the leather. Gently rub the eraser against the scuff, clearing any eraser shavings as you work. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Spray glass cleaner on a paper towel and wipe the bag thoroughly.
steps.content: Spray glass cleaner on a paper towel and wipe the bag thoroughly. Wipe the paper towel in circular motions to pick up dust and polish the surface of the bag. This should remove most dust and dirt.

steps.title: Apply petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol to tough scuffs.
steps.content: Apply petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol to tough scuffs. Using a paper towel or a cotton swab, apply a small amount of petroleum jelly or rubbing alcohol to the mark. Try the petroleum jelly first, as rubbing alcohol is a paint stripper and should be used sparingly. Wipe the area off with a dry cloth after a few moments. If the mark is particularly stubborn, you can apply a bit of pressure as you rub the cotton swab or paper towel into the mark.

steps.title: Wipe the bag using a mixture of mild soap and distilled water.
steps.content: Wipe the bag using a mixture of mild soap and distilled water. Dampen a soft cloth and add 1 small drop of non-detergent cleaner to the surface of the cloth. Apply the gentle cleaning solution all over the bag in circular motions. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Use a dry cloth to wipe the bag dry.
steps.content: Use a dry cloth to wipe the bag dry. Make sure the entire bag is dry, including any spots that have handles, rivets, or crevices. You might want to allow it to dry overnight before placing it in a dust cover for storage. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Store your bag in a safe and dry location.
steps.content: Store your bag in a safe and dry location. After cleaning, make sure you place the bag, in its dust cover, in a location that is safe for long-term storage. If you don’t have a dust cover, you can order one online base on the size of your bag. Your storage space for your bag should be room-temperature and low-humidity. [25] X Research source
